articles.headline: Google Is Teaching Children How to Act Online. Is It the Best Role Model?
articles.snippet: The tech giant is positioning itself in schools as a trusted authority on digital citizenship at a moment when the company’s data-handling practices are under growing scrutiny.
articles.abstract: The tech giant is positioning itself in schools as a trusted authority on digital citizenship at a moment when the company’s data-handling practices are under growing scrutiny.
articles.lead_paragraph: Google is on a mission to teach children how to be safe online. That is the message behind “Be Internet Awesome,” a so-called digital-citizenship education program that the technology giant developed for schools.
articles.byline: By Natasha Singer and Sapna Maheshwari

articles.headline: This Thermometer Tells Your Temperature, Then Tells Firms Where to Advertise
articles.snippet: Clorox is using data from so-called smart thermometers to target ads to areas where people are sick. It’s the latest example of internet-connected devices being used for advertising.
articles.abstract: Clorox is using data from so-called smart thermometers to target ads to areas where people are sick. It’s the latest example of internet-connected devices being used for advertising.
articles.lead_paragraph: Most of what we do — the websites we visit, the places we go, the TV shows we watch, the products we buy — has become fair game for advertisers. Now, thanks to internet-connected devices in the home like smart thermometers, ads we see may be determined by something even more personal: our health.

articles.headline: When Sears Flourished, So Did Workers. At Amazon, It’s More Complicated.
articles.snippet: Profit-sharing plans for rank-and-file employees are vanishing as corporate America has adopted a new approach toward who reaps a healthy company’s gains.
articles.abstract: Profit-sharing plans for rank-and-file employees are vanishing as corporate America has adopted a new approach toward who reaps a healthy company’s gains.
articles.lead_paragraph: Half a century ago, a typical Sears salesman could walk out of the store at retirement with a nest egg worth well over a million in today’s dollars, feathered with company stock. A warehouse worker hired now at Amazon who stays until retirement would leave with a fraction of that.
articles.byline: By Nelson D. Schwartz and Michael Corkery

articles.headline: Battling Dementia, Sandra Day O’Connor Leaves Public Life With Plea for Bipartisanship
articles.snippet: Justice O’Connor, 88, was the first woman to serve on the Supreme Court. She wielded immense power and often found ways to bridge divides in a less polarized era.
articles.abstract: Justice O’Connor, 88, was the first woman to serve on the Supreme Court. She wielded immense power and often found ways to bridge divides in a less polarized era.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The first woman to serve on the Supreme Court was just 75, young by its standards, and still sharp and vigorous when she left. But she gave up the job she loved, along with extraordinary power, to guide and comfort her husband, who was struggling with Alzheimer’s disease.

articles.headline: What Could Kill Booming U.S. Economy? ‘Socialists,’ White House Warns
articles.snippet: A report from the Council of Economic Advisers compares Bernie Sanders to Chairman Mao, and warns that pickup trucks cost more in Sweden.
articles.abstract: A report from the Council of Economic Advisers compares Bernie Sanders to Chairman Mao, and warns that pickup trucks cost more in Sweden.
articles.lead_paragraph: Karl Marx. Vladimir Lenin. Mao Zedong. Elizabeth Warren?
articles.byline: By Binyamin Appelbaum and Jim Tankersley

articles.headline: Prince and President Escalate Battle Over Khashoggi Killing
articles.snippet: For the strongmen of Turkey and Saudi Arabia, the fight over the killing of a dissident is personal and political.
articles.abstract: For the strongmen of Turkey and Saudi Arabia, the fight over the killing of a dissident is personal and political.
articles.lead_paragraph: ISTANBUL — President Recep Tayyip Erdogan of Turkey swept into Ankara’s wood-paneled Parliament on Tuesday to level his most direct attack yet against Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman of Saudi Arabia, accusing his government of planning the “savage murder” and mutilation of the dissident writer Jamal Khashoggi.
articles.byline: By David D. Kirkpatrick and Carlotta Gall

articles.headline: The Problem With Fixing WhatsApp? Human Nature Might Get in the Way
articles.snippet: The messaging app, which is owned by Facebook, has been slow to address false news on its service. The problem may be less the company or product, and more WhatsApp the idea.
articles.abstract: The messaging app, which is owned by Facebook, has been slow to address false news on its service. The problem may be less the company or product, and more WhatsApp the idea.
articles.lead_paragraph: Should the world worry about WhatsApp? Has it become a virulent new force in global misinformation and political trickery?

articles.headline: Saudi Crown Prince Calls Khashoggi’s Death ‘Heinous’
articles.snippet: It was the crown prince’s most public comment since the backlash over the Oct. 2 killing of the Saudi critic Jamal Khashoggi began roiling the kingdom.
articles.abstract: It was the crown prince’s most public comment since the backlash over the Oct. 2 killing of the Saudi critic Jamal Khashoggi began roiling the kingdom.
articles.lead_paragraph: RIYADH, Saudi Arabia — The crown prince of Saudi Arabia on Wednesday denounced the “heinous crime” committed against Jamal Khashoggi, the dissident writer killed in Turkey. It was his most public attempt yet to separate himself from Saudi operatives suspected of the killing, who include some of the crown prince’s own aides.
